{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3353509,"name":"Jared","username":"jlevin378","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T20:30:03.137Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone,

I am trying to position based PID tune a brushed linear actuator controlled by a SparkMAX, and am having trouble seeing any results. No matter what I change my PID related constants to, I seem to get no change in my results. Below are the files involved in my PID tuning, as well as a link to the linear actuator in use. If anyone could possibly help me to understand why my code may not work, or if it appears correct, please possibly help me to understand how to do PID tuning more accurately, as it is possible I am simply doing things wrong in terms of the actual tuning.

Thank you for your time!

Code:

gist.github.com

https://gist.github.com/vAnomali/65752a07aa30d2063b2d771523537191

Constants.java
package frc.robot;

import com.revrobotics.CANSparkMax.IdleMode;

public class Constants {

    public final static class GlobalConstants{
        // Given side of a mechanism 
        
		public static enum RobotSide{
This file has been truncated. show original

GitHub","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62764,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/position-based-pid-tuning/461474/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3353561,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T21:51:38.921Z","cooked":"

It doesn’t look like you’re attempting to use the PID Controller.

The linearUp() and linearDown() methods just set the motor controller to output 100% (or 0%) duty cycle in the forward and reverse directions, ignoring the PID Controller.

There is one call to setReference (the way you give the PID Controller a setpoint) – line 213:

p_linear1.setReference(newVal, ControlType.kPosition);

And it’s called from periodic(), but newVal is always 0.0.

So are you saying if the checkPIDGains() function were called in each call to go up or down, it could fix the issue? I understand what you are saying the issue is, but am not fully understanding of how to properly integrate a fix. Also thank you very much for the response!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-04-06T22:07:49.699Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":77,"readers_count":76,"score":15.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":461474,"topic_slug":"position-based-pid-tuning","display_username":"Jared","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":7334,"username":"usbcd36","name":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62764,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/position-based-pid-tuning/461474/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3353588,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T23:10:40.916Z","cooked":"

It would help greatly if you’d post a link to your entire code project. This would help me understand how your commands work, how they’re being scheduled, etc…

Also, it would help if you could describe the expected behavior, versus the observed behavior. There are many ways for something to not produce the desired results.

Looking at the code again, what I said before isn’t quite right: newVal won’t always be 0.0; it should be able to pull setpoints from networktables/dashboard if ENABLE_TEST_DASHBOARDS is true – you’d have to open up Glass or Shuffleboard or something and enter a value for “actuator-setpoint”. That said, I expect that this is intended to be “tuning mode”, and that you don’t want to be entering setpoints manually.

This is where the stuff above comes into play – if I understand how you want the code to behave and can see the code you’ve written for that purpose, I can help you make it work.

Here is the link to our branch, it is called actuators but should contain all of the bots most up-to-date code (I am bad at GitHub!).

I will also add what you noted about the ENABLE_TEST_DASHBOARDS, I did not notice I had forgotten that. That being said, I tried PID tuning other systems where I did have that, and I believe it still was not working so there may be other issues at hand.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-04-06T23:21:14.173Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":44,"readers_count":43,"score":8.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461474,"topic_slug":"position-based-pid-tuning","display_username":"Jared","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":62764,"username":"jlevin378","name":"Jared","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/ccd318/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62764,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/position-based-pid-tuning/461474/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3353626,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-07T00:11:34.198Z","cooked":"

So, it looks like your commands are:

  • InitDiggingActuator
  • LowerDiggingActuator
  • RaiseDiggingActuator

Init controls the subsystem through linearActuatorInitEnd, which calls linearStop

Lower and Raise interact with the subsystem through linearActuator(LinearActuatorState)

Combined, the main control interface of the subsystem is really just:

  • linearUp
  • linearDown
  • linearStop

The problem is, the code is full of potential conflicts. There are several ways that the motor controllers could be commanded to do two different things during one 20ms iteration cycle, since commands, the subsystem, and the linearNotifier all have the ability to call linearUp/Down/Stop.

To fix this:

  • Remove the linearNotifier and checkLimits and configure the SPARK MAX to use soft limits instead.

  • Remove the call “p_linear1.setReference(newVal, ControlType.kPosition);” from checkPIDGains; you don’t want to create a conflict in controlling the motor. Add a method, say linearDashboardSetpoint that pulls the value from the NetworkTables for when you want to use tuning mode. Write a command that calls this from its execute method.

  • Change the LowerDiggingActuator and RaiseDiggingActuator commands to call linearDown and linearUp from execute instead of initialize. Change linearDown/Up to call setReference on p_linear1 instead of set on m_linear1 – you want to feed setpoints to the PID Controller, not override it and control the SPARK MAX output directly.

  • Remove the call that causes m_linear2 to follow m_linear1. Everywhere that you feed a setpoint to p_linear1, add a similar line to feed that setpoint to p_linear2 – you want each actuator to use its own encoder for feedback.

  • Set p_linear1 to use the encoder a_linear1 (and the same for p_linear2 and a_linear2).

controller","slug":"spark-max-pid-controller-vs-wpilib-pid-controller","posts_count":19,"reply_count":14,"highest_post_number":19,"image_url":null,"created_at":"2025-01-18T00:08:32.206Z","last_posted_at":"2025-01-24T16:04:00.870Z","bumped":true,"bumped_at":"2025-01-24T16:04:00.870Z","archetype":"regular","unseen":false,"pinned":false,"unpinned":null,"excerpt":"Not
